Deshaye has a unique way of connecting poems from 200 years ago with modern currents of thought and multi-media additions like Led Zeppelin and Feist. He provides well thought views about the value of art and WILL help improve your writing!

The class content was really boring at first because it was mostly just grammar and writing skills but it got more interesting. Readings weren't necessary, you could still usually participate in class discussions without having done them. Gives a lot of really good feedback on writing assignments and is willing to give you extra help if needed.
An amazing prof. Intelligent...great lectures (clear)--insightful thoughts on your comments...really cute

Joel is intelligent and offers amazing insight into the works used in class. Very approachable for help; your writing will improve greatly if you take the time to seek him out with questions. He's cute and funny, too, which makes conference attendance even more fun!
No Comments
Great teacher, very nice, very helpful. Just a genuinely good guy and professor.
Super nice professor, very patient to students.
He is one of the best prof ever at McGill.
Prof. Wang is one of the best profs I have ever had at McGill! Super clear as to what he wants on assignments/exams and cares about his students dearly. Take him if possible!
Derek is the nicest professor ever! His slides, examples, and explanations are clear and he lets you know exactly what to study for the exams. Also his subtle jokes are pretty funny
Very clear and pleasant instructor.

Best professor I had at McGill. She is fun, engaging, inspiring, organized, and just so nice. I also loved the fact that she treats us like adults who are about to get in real world. One tip: read the cases before class, and participate in the case discussion. That's the way to go to get most out of this class, get a good grade, and have fun.

It's really rare to have a professor who teaches the material but who is also very involved in giving values and a lesson of life, and who listens to the students. Taking her class has really broadened my horizons!

Very engaging professor, with lots of practical experience. She is knowledgeable and very open personality. Extremely helpful after class and always available on skype! You must prepare case studies at home and participate in class to get a good grade.
Great teaching style! Inspires students to be more innovative and open-minded. Available all the time via email, skype, consulting hours...Take her!

A fantastic instructor. Strived to ensure students understood concepts, and would frequently engage the class in very interesting discussions. Homework was fair (although heavy at time), but very necessary and helpful in the long-term. Consistent and timely completion of homework made studying for tests much easier. Overall, very good course.

This course helped me a lot and I feel much more confident in Russian now. Our teacher played a major role in achieving that. I hope many others will benefit from this course and her expertise. We had a lot of work, but it was worth it for the course especially because it is an advanced course.

Dr. Klimanova assigns so much homework, and the root quizzes/vocab tests killed everyone- even the native speakers/grad students. At the end of the semester, though, she takes into account your improvement and effort and is very generous with the final grade.

Dr. Klimanova is a really sweet person, but taking her class means you'd better get to work. This is an advanced course, but there were times where even the grad students felt overworked. You'll learn a lot with her, but you'll struggle just as much to learn. The assignments are killer, but do extra credit and rewrite the essays & you'll be fine!

This course was very interactive, which is very useful for language acquisition. There were many opportunity to get good grades i.e.: tests, many quizzes, presentations etc. I actually loved this course. I not only learned a great deal but had a lot of fun learning it. Dr. Klimanova is a very engaging and supportive teacher!

Take this class if you want an easy A. If you actually care about learning Russian, it won't be so useful to take it. You will see the most basic information helping you start with the Russian language, nothing more. No final exam.

Her teaching methods, approachability, and expertise are exactly what a student needs when learning Russian as a foreign language. She is fair, and wants her students to do well. She has high expectations, which we all work to meet.

Great teacher! Teaching a language is not easy! It's not simply a matter of knowing the language, and it's not simply a matter of knowing how to teach. This is truly a challenging field to be an educator and Dr. Klimanova excels at it. She also happens to be a lovely person, with a great personality, always making class fun and engaging.

had her for both Elem. Russ and Interm. Russ, and will say - she is rather average. Those who like her are the ones who don't know what a good l-ge teacher can be. She kind of ingratiates herself to stdnts so that she's liked & they keep taking Russ, but she teaches little &barely explains, esp. in Intrm. So, if u want an easy grade, u'll like it.
Prof. Klimanova is a fantastic teacher.
Professor Klimanova is a beaut! Great teacher and person.

Great prof, hilarious. Really clear study guides, clear about what will be on tests (less so on quizzes but its still ok). LOTS of homework but she is understanding if its late from time to time. Don't skip class, honestly, you'll just screw yourself over. If you keep up with assignments and study a couple hours for each test you'll get an A.
She is awesome. She motivates her students to learn and uses many tools to let them understand and keep what they learnt for their life time.

He's smart and young. He can explain the topics and concepts at a level where everyone can understand. This is quite a difficult course but because it is fair, it's not that bad. If you put in the work, you should be rewarded. Practice is about the same caliber as the exams. He's nicer to Continuing Education Students. Strong recommendation.

He's super smart and because he's so young, can explain the topics and concepts at a level where everyone can understand. This is quite a difficult course but because it is fair, it's not that bad. If you put in the work, you should be rewarded. Practice is about the same caliber as the exams. Case is graded severely. Strong recommendation.

Marc is an amazing prof, who makes sure that every one of his students is involved and included. He is always available to give pointers and help, the course content is just so fascinating, and the discussion is always lively. Definitely make a point to be in his conference section.

This was the best class I've ever taken at McGill, and Marc is my new favorite prof. If you have any interest in the material, you need to take this class. However, a lot of people found him/the TAs to be hard markers. I think I only did well because I have a writing style similar to his and went to his office hours before each paper.

Marc was really accessible and helpful outside of class, and he made a point to learn the names of most everyone in his lectures, but his lectures themselves seemed incredibly saturated and didn't follow a chronological order. He is also a tough grader which is a disadvantage in such a subjective class when he doesn't agree with your essay points.

Professor Ducusin was absolutely amazing. His lectures were always fascinating and very thought-provoking. I learned so much in this class, and I will be thinking about the things I learned for the rest of my life. I highly recommend this class, the assignments aren't very difficult and there's no exams. Plus, the material is very interesting.

Be very careful which TA you choose for this course. Marc is crystal clear but the TAs can be rough in the grading. Also make sure writing papers does not bother you as the course is only graded on papers. Average was B.
Very nice lecturer, extremely helpful regarding any matter. Lectures can sometimes be a bit slow but he is easy on the eye so it's ok
Great professor.
Top end professor.

Stylish scarf. Very friendly, and encourages questions in class. Can be somewhat disorganized during lectures, but provides all you need to know. Textbook is an online set of notes, which are far less clear and concise than he is. Writes a detailed study guide before final, which tells you what proofs to memorize, and has many sample questions.

This man is amazing. He teaches in a very clear, casual manner. His enthusiasm for math and genuine concern for his students' understanding of the material creates a low stress classroom environment which is ideal for higher level math courses. Honestly I would go out of my way to rearrange my schedule if it meant I could sit in his lectures again.

The class is okay. The graders are hard and have weird criteria. One of those 200 level classes where they try their hardest to give the least As possible, but a good grade is still relatively effortless. He speaks SOOOO slowly, just skip class and listen to his lectures at twice the speed to save yourself the suffering.

Pretty easy and interesting class. Holland is a really sweet prof who gives a lot into his lectures, although they are really optional because everything is on the slides. Readings don't need to be done. Midterm and finals are super fair.
Clear and relatively easy class. Work required but overall enjoyable
You have to attend the lectures. They're full of information that is not on the slides, but they're also hilarious. Take any class with him, you'll enjoy it.

Sean has been great this semester, his lectures are interesting and tests haven't been too hard. We had to write an 8-page term paper, but as long as you followed his instructions and attended class, you would most likely do well. Overall would take a class with him again.
BIG FAN

I was enthusiastic about this class but didn't learn much beyond what I already knew. I found that much of the material was presented in a superficial way. The prof was entertaining but he seemed to lack in-depth knowledge of some of the topics we discussed. Overall: take it if you want a 'fun' class, stay away if you want serious learning.

He's a fantastic lecturer who makes lots of jokes and knows how to keep the class paying attention. His tests were very fair. The term paper however had pretty heavy length/research requirements considering it was only worth 25% of a 300 level course. He's young and very easy on the eyes, I'd ask him out if we met under different circumstances haha

One of my favourite profs after 5 years at McGill. Took Deviance and Crime with him and loved both (although the content is very similar). Makes his content super relatable and clear and he marks very fairly. Attendance is important because it's part of the mark and what he says in class is probably the most valuable when studying for his exams.

Sean is very accessible, makes himself available for his students as much as possible and encourages us to come to ask questions. His lectures are clear and organized and move at an adequate pace. He assigns lots of readings but takes the time to go over them in class. Overall his class is very interesting and and is taught in a very lively manner.

If you just want to take a random soci class, TAKE HIS CLASSES. Whether it's Crime or Deviance, you'll have a blast because he's literally the most entertaining prof I've ever had at McGill. He's obviously passionate about his research and he makes you care about it too while being absolutely hilarious while doing so.
Straight up the funniest prof I've ever had. So charismatic and fun, while still managing to get the information across clearly. 10/10
Awesome prof! Plus he's a total babe

Awesome prof!!!! Took his deviance and crime class. He's super engaging and passionate about the material. he is also very knowledgeable and approachable. Exams are pretty easy. Attendance is a must if you wanna do well. Reading are good to do but you'll be fine if you don't!! Really recommend him

Took his Deviance Class over the summer. I've never been so eager to be up for an 8.30 class in my life: Most fun and engaging prof I've had at McGill. You'll do well if you attend all the lectures (doing the readings wasn't super necessary, but best if you want an A rather than a B). Exams were not hard, and attendance was taken.

First class of its kind I took, and inspired me to pursue a minor in Social Studies of Medicine. She teaches fascinating concepts clearly and backs it up with some of the best readings I've ever done. Encourages participation, active engagement.

I took two courses with her (Anth 227) and the next level, New Horizons in Medical Anthropology. I don't put this lightly when I say she is inspirational. eEvery reading she chooses is interesting and she makes really salient points and is a pretty nice grader when it comes to papers

Took during summer. Attendance/participation was 10%. She wants you to actively engage and discuss in class, and you should, as you'll take away a lot from the class! Inspired me to pursue a minor in Social Studies of Medicine. Tests were fair and straightforward, not tricky at all. Readings were fascinating (I don't say that lightly).
There is 10% for in-class participation and attendance. Register for this course during Summer: groups are smaller and the learning environment is fast-paced.
New teacher but knows what she is doing, I would take another class with her.
Genuinely cares about her students!

Gives good lectures, that prepare us well for the short weekly assignments and tests. She gives in class polling questions that make us reflect on the material and also for checking attendance (for small amount of final grade). Exams are very fair and consist of explaining concepts saw in class in a few sentences. Overall very easy and enjoyable.

Understanding Planet Earth a mix of gr9 science and geography content. Memorization is required to an extent, but the content is not difficult if you're interested. Prof is super sweet too. Midterm and final gives you choice of questions (i.e. choose 5 of 8 to answer), so pretty much an easy grade if you pay attention and study a bit.
Very dynamic, but the exams were so tricky!!
Really tricky exam questions but her lectures are good. She keeps things interesting and is willing to clarify.

I absolutely loved Professor Human! I found the class extremely enjoyable with very engaging material. The exam questions were tricky at times but straightforward if you knew the studies very well.. I would definitely take her again! (Also gives you up to 4% extra credit!!)

I took social psych with this prof and the course was very interesting! She put a lot of effort into her lectures, even the PowerPoints were well done (a lot of great pictures and were very concise). If you listen in class and read the textbook, you'll do well. Read exam questions carefully because the wording may be misleading sometimes.

The professor is very nice and tries to make the material more interesting by adding in TV show examples. The questions' phrasing was very frustrating, having TAs at times agree and answer yeah maybe talk to the professor about that. Material wise pretty fun and simple, the questions less so but the professor did change marks after some discussions

Prof Human is really friendly and a good lecturer! Her exams are kind of tricky, so get ready to know every detail of many many studies and read the textbook. I liked how she gave us the opportunity for bonus points by participating in in-class polling. I would definitely take her again!

Materials themselves are very not hard to understand, but exam questions are full of nuance. She is a very good lecturer, very humorous, elegant, slides are well-organised. I don't recommend you to take it, if it is your FIRST PSYC course.

Engaging lectures- you won't find yourself getting bored. Knows how to keep the material relatable and interesting. Fair grading and bonus participation marks are awarded if you come to class and poll. would love to have her as a prof again.

I really enjoyed her class. Her lectures are engaging and she is extremely passionate about the topic. I had a heavy course load in my other classes and put minimally effort in. Her exams weren't easy but I didn't find them unfair at all. I'd definitely recommend reading the textbook. All I did for studying was memorize the definitions from book.

Human is a very intelligent lecturer. Her exam questions were those that made me think and felt like I was using my brain. She is also here if you want her to clarify experiments/ concepts mentioned in class. Good lecturer. Definitely recommend it!

Dr. Human made attending 8:30 classes enjoyable. She is super passionate about the social psychology, and does an awesome job of making the content relevant. She is also very helpful when you ask questions outside of class. Her exams are very tricky, but she curves if the average is too low. Take a class with her if you can!

Overall this was a fun course. However, her exams were very tricky and difficult (Average 63 - that she rounded up to 70). Course material is very interesting. Be ready to read a lot , 20% of exam questions based on textbook.

Professor Human is great, she really tries to make her lectures interesting. She keeps students involved with interesting polls, relates the content to funny TV shows and real world examples, and also includes TED Talks / guest speakers in her lectures. Her exams are a bit tricky, but a a very interesting class and a great proff!

She is a very good professor who genuinely wants her students to learn. She is very approachable and is very helpful when you go see her one on one. The material presented was interesting. The class is mostly discussion. There are a lot of readings and weekly papers but it totally doable if you are interested in social psychology!
Very nice prof, makes discussion easy, is clear in her expectations/grading, and gives a reasonable amount of work! Learned a lot from her class.

I really liked her. She makes the material relevant and uses really good examples. She moves kinda quickly so sometimes it can be hard to keep up. Exams were a bit tricky. I found this class so interesting and really enjoyed it. I did not do very well but I would take this again. I loved the topics and just found it so interesting.
Great prof. Gives a lot of energy to the class (even if it starts at 8:30). If you go to her office hours she might look like she is mad at you but she isn't, she is just like that with everybody.
Funny and very knowledgeable about materials.

I've taken two courses with her, and she is, hands down, the best university instructor I have ever had. I'm a better teacher and a better person for what I've learned from this woman. She has high expectations and she will guide you every step of the way. She is an actual pro.

I have been in University for over six years and I can honestly say Megan was the worst professor I ever had. She seems nice on the surface, but she has her clear favourites. If you're not on her 'list', enjoy your C/B grade. She's failed multiple people's self-reflections because it doesn't conform to HER style of teaching. AVOID taking her!!!

LOVED Megan. She has a lot of experience teaching high school students and is capable of sharing it with future teachers. She also does a great job in relating theory to practice and in motivating us student teachers to become great and inspiring educators. She assigns complex assignments but is always available to help you out with your ideas!

AMAZING prof. I am in my third year at McGill and Megan is the only education teacher I actually learnt something with. Her classes are not only theory based, she actually gives examples of how to bring theory into practice. TAKE HER.

Kim is clearly very intelligent, but her lectures aren't very enlightening; she doesn't add much clarity to the material. Just read the assigned papers and go to conferences and you'll do fine. Conferences are mandatory, and there is a participation grade for those, but you can skip every class, read the slides/articles, and still do well.
The topic is interesting and the debates in class are food for thought. Prof. Kim is very knowledgeable and helpful with students.

I'm sure that she's a great researcher, but she is a terrible prof. Her lectures are given too fast, and shes so nervous and unsure of herself that she cant answer simple questions on the topic. There is a language barrier so I understand that some difficulties arise from that, but- in the nicest way I can possibly say this- she shouldnt be a prof.
Inspirational, Young and Handsome. Very open minded but consistent with rules. No spoon feeding. Lot of pleasure doing assignments. Enjoys having beer with older students.

I wanted to like you, seriously, I wanted to enjoy your class but you made that so difficult for me. The only blessing was that there was only 1 lecture a week. The midterm was a map exam, 20 short answer and 2 essays in an hour and a half, which was doable, but unnecessary. Final was take-home. Conferences were quite enjoyable though.

Passing this class was utterly easy, and you must be very dumb to fail. This is the kind of teaching I prefer, it allows to actually enjoy the subject instead of trying to stuff dates and names in my brain.
A very nice teacher
Great class! Would take for credit again.

Isabel's class was very easy, as for most basic history classes. Going to lectures did not really help since she is reading her slides for most of it, although she sometimes gave cues about what would be in the exam. Also lots of reading to do but I realized that the important info is in the power points, so I assume you can survive without reading

I liked Isabel. I felt the subject was rushed through, but it's hard to include many details in such short time. I also liked the conferences we had to attend to, it's something I had never seen before. Although the grading was tough, I must admit that I enjoyed this class!
Great lectures! Very interesting class and I liked the use of personal pictures of the sights in her power points. Also very helpful when you ask her questions!

Isabel is very good in her field. If you are interested in history, you will like her lectures, and if you take the time to learn the slides for the exam you will get a good grade. Excellent class and prof.
Great teacher. I appreciated that she gave us the chance to talk about the American elections in class.

Not an interesting lecturer. Her Powerpoint's were very dense and she went through them fast making note taking difficult. She is a fair grader and gave a reasonable number of assignments. The readings assigned were very dense, but you can get by without reading most of them (just make sure to prepare for the conferences).
One of the best teachers I've ever had. She was dedicated to the class and replied to my mails really quickly. Great class!

I really liked Isabel. It is quite difficult to present more than a thousand year of history in one class, but she did it well. She was funny and accessible, trying to link things that happened in the past with popular culture or.... her travels! We have to study and work to get good grades, but that is usual at university level.

The class was according to my expectations, and I found the presentation by the professor for most parts clear and fetching. True, she had some French accent, but with a bit of concentration and the thorough slides, even a non-native English speaker like me was well able to follow the class. She responded quickly to e-Mails and was very helpful.

Her power points were completely useless and she just read off the slides, giving no extra information and didn't explain the events clearly at all. I ended up skipping most of the lectures because they were a waste of my time. She is also hard to understand when she speaks. The midterm was way harder than a 200 level course should be.

Overall, this class felt like a High School history class. I learned nothing and was thoroughly disappointed by the Prof's inability to adequately answer a question and the inaccurate information displayed on the powerpoint. The TAs did a great job though and were probably more qualified to teach the class than she was.

Awesome guy! He makes class very entertaining + interesting but not too patient at explaining in person, he's better at discussion board answers. The notes are very clear, you can easily skip classes and succeed. The midterm, assignments, and final were extremely fair, exactly what he told us what to expect. TAs not that great though. Recommend.

If you are in Science faculty or Engineering, you'll find Andrew to be one of the best profs. He's very funny and very knowledgeable in Physics. However, he does have a little trouble explaining physics if you haven't taken physics before. However, his test are pretty easy.

Funniest prof ever. He made the course content interesting and he was always so energetic about teaching it. Great, fun course (I took it as an elective). No textbook, good notes, short weekly assignments. Easy midterm (final is next week). Overall nice dude. Cares a lot about explaining concepts clearly, even if it takes a couple tries :P
Best lecturer in McGill. He really goes deep in the material and explains everything with a lot of examples. This course was recorded so you can get a good grade even if you don't go to class.

Prof Holmes is knowledgeable, caring, and fair. I enjoyed having her as a professor, but she comes off as a show-off and tries too hard to be relatable to students. She struts around the lecture hall and talks about her social life a lot, which is frankly, a bit unprofessional and unnecessary. Nevertheless, she's a great prof w a bold personality.

This prof is like a music encyclopedia. Her passion for teaching and music is clear and she's a very engaging public speaker. She goes the extra mile to help her students and dumb down music concepts. Her class was an easy A with easy assignments. Shes also fun and fresh as a young prof + amazing to look at/watch ;) McGill is lucky to have her.

I really liked her the first few lectures, but her big personality gets tiresome. She is super knowledgable about music but shows-off a lot (about her social and academic life) and tries hard to be relatable. Some people like this type of teacher though! She's got an engaging and youthful personality and I'm sure is a great person. She's self-aware

Best prof ever! Loved her Art of Listening class. She's a dreamy goddess that makes learning fun and makes you want to come to class. Loved how she uses emojis in her music charts. Option of working in groups for assignments was nice. She is very good with emails and extra help in office hours.

prof. Holmes is stunning, wicked smart & cool and really cares about her students which shows in how she learned our names. I learned so much from this prof and she inspired me to love classical music. We didn't need to buy the textbook TBH since she explained everything clearly in lectures. Can't beat a smokin hot prof who can sing & play cello!

Amazing prof, fantastic lectures, David will make you love the language. He truly cares about his students and their success in the class. You will learn SO MUCH. If you put in the required efforts the class is not difficult. David is the reason I stayed at McGill. If you get the chance to have him as a teacher DO NOT hesitate!
He is great, clear and helps you learn a lot

David is such a sweet professor. Hontesly if you work hard enough it'll be a breeze. I really enjoy his lectures. He always speaks in Spanish and he has a very good relationship with students. Just don't take the 8:30am class, it's hard to get up in the morning.
Best math prof at McGill. Had him for 263, he actually knows how to explain concepts as proved by his 80% class average.
Best prof in McGill, cares about students. Exams are fair.

Amazing teacher! Had him for a communication in Education class and he was just amazing! Was very nice and caring to the students, very understanding. Sometimes the class doesn't pay attention and he has trouble getting everyone settled down but other than that nothing else is bad. Easy A class.

Took MUAR201 with him last year and I decided to take MUAR374 solely because he was teaching. He knows the material really well. I really enjoy going to class. Exams are fair, he always makes sure that we know what would be on the exam.
An enthused character who loves what he does and that reverberates throughout the class. Easily accessible and goes above and beyond for each student. Very caring! Overall an awesome guy:)
Sweet!
Amazing lectures ! Caring professor. He really knows his stuff and makes it captivating and easy to understand. 100% recommend.
just love him. he's passionate about music and very prepared for lectures. would definitely take future classes with him.
One of my favourite professors in my four years at McGill! 100% recommend this course. Interesting and fun!

great guy, really clear slides and made the class super interesting. exams are fairly easy as most of the questions come directly from information in the slides or (more rarely) from the readings. he goes over the readings in class so don't worry too much about actually reading in depth. term paper was really fun to write
Great guy overall. Cares about his students and wants them to care about the material
Solid guy!
Nothing but love for Jon Wild

Totally recommended for the course "Topics in Tonal Analysis" which was great and unlike any other course I've ever taken. He found really cool repertoire and gave us lots of freedom in our projects. Asked for lots of work but it was enjoyable.

Fantastic music analysis teacher. We spent a lot of time on each piece and looked in depth at how the music worked. He has passion for music & theory & for sharing his understanding, and his enthusiasm was contagious. Feedback on homework was done in class, not so much individually (but he was very helpful outside of class when I asked questions)
He was THE most Amazing Professor in my first semester in McGill. I really miss his kindness and genuine integrity. The course was brilliant.

I had no background in music theory, and yes the class was more involved than I thought. But this is such a smart guy, I appreciated his lectures so much. I did well & want to learn more. I recommend J.Wild very highly but this isn't a bird course. Not much use of the textbook apart from problem sets- he made a lot of his own materials, it seemed.

If you have no previous music knowledge, the class is very difficult. He gives a lot of assignments, so as long as you do those, you can get a decent grade with some effort. Fair warning though, this is NOT a beginner's course, at least, not with this professor.

He is soooo hot!I've trained in piano for over 10 years but lack knowledge in theories. This course is very helpful but when it comes to final, it gets harder and boring. overall i like the pro!!!He is always there to help. TA hold tutorial all the time.

MUAR 201 Basic Materials: Western Music was an easy elective for me- as I have had much previous knowledge of music theory prior to this class. However, for those who have little to no music theory knowledge, this class can be pretty difficult. He was friendly, easy to understand and always had the best interest in his students :)

He is an excellent explainer of things! After years of playing an instrument but not paying attention to how the music is written, a lot of things are clear to me now after a month in Prof Wild's class. There is a friendly atmosphere in class and his examples at the piano are great. I wish he gave more written notes in addition to the text though.
Modal counterpoint as professor Wild teaches it is without a doubt the most enjoyable class I have yet taken in university. He is a master in his field and in teaching effectively.
Best theory teacher

Prof Wild was my best theory teacher in 4 years at McGill. He won a prize at our graduation ceremony after being nominated by students. All of my friends in my year agreed he had been our favorite (theory) teacher.
Fine teacher, interesting and funny man, this class is not too demanding. I can haz Jon Wild's baby?

I can't believe the previous review... in our class (20th century analysis) Professor Wild is very pleasant. he is always interesting to listen to, and CLEARabout what ever he explains. A very good musician and kind man who let me hand in my assignment late when I had an emergency. And I am getting more interested in the material now...

We received no feedback on our work, and yet he expects us to somehow divine his criteria for good research and writing. He was often totally unprepared, an intellectual bully at times, dominating the discussions with passive judgement and undercutting. I don't recommend him as a professor.

Best professor in first year required courses. His Britishness makes the course very bearable. His lectures are excellent and he's a great speaker and keeps the students entertained with making small British-like jokes while doing Counterpoint cleverly.
A great, funny guy who really knows how to teach this stuff. he's very clear, and if he even thinks he wasn't he'll send out an email to the entire class. a great guy overall :)
Excellent
He's british, and funny, and made me not hate counterpoint. I thought his lectures were very clear and he seemed really helpful and open to questions.

The course is awful, and unfortunately it's required. Unless you're an Early Music major, this won't be fun for you. On the bright side, Professor Wild is a great teacher who adds a lot of structure and clarity to a difficult subject. He sticks to the text book most of the time, so review is easy.

Awesome guy. He speaks very clearly and teaches the material very well. You can tell he really loves what he's teaching and always welcomes students' comments and questions. The workload and exams were fair but you do have to take the time to study the textbook to really do well.

I found this to be a really easy and enjoyable class. Your entire grade is based off two midterms and a final, which are all over half multiple choice. There are no essays!!! :D Also, hes a super chill guy and really good teacher who makes the material very interesting

Super interesting class, Dario is very clear and presents information in an interesting and "digestible" way. Significant memorization for the exams (and a lot of material) but they are fairly straightforward- if you listen well and study adequately, quite easy to do well!

Such as sweet professor who genuinely cares about what he is teaching plus wants all his students to succeed! There is a lot of course material to memorize for the course but his exams are pretty fair and you can do well if you put in the time!

Honestly the best prof I have had at McGill. His lectures may get a bit boring sometimes, but overall he makes sure to explain everything clearly, and is always open to questions. His tests are straightforward, and the only thing that's hard is remembering all the dates and places.
Straightford. Everything on the slide or textbook is fair game so understand big concepts as well as smaller facts. Really interesting course.
His lectures are entertaining and engaging. On any issue or idea, he makes sure to address and consider all perspectives. Great class and awesome professor!

Actually an awesome prof. Concepts are really well explained, the workload is what you'd expect. It's possible to do really well if you put the work in. Above all, Dario is super passionate about his field, which translates into the lectures. His classes are rarely boring and worth attending, even if attendance isn' t mandatory. TAKE THIS PROF!!
A great professor who clearly has a passion for archaeology. The exams are very fair and are made up of multiple choice and long answer. Do the readings and know the power points, and you'll do well.

The professor is one of a kind, dont get me wrong. But i feel like the way ANTH 201 was structured in winter 2017 was just insanely difficult. we had two midterms, and a final. Lectures were 60 pages long slides, with information bulldozed on you and expectations to memorise each word, because his MCQ questions were made by him that way.

Dario was a great prof! Really knows his stuff and is a really nice and caring guy. The exams have short/long answer questions so you def have to study for them, but he is an easy grader and is open to extra credit. I really recommend this prof!!!

Amazing teacher! Absolutely adore Dario! His class is easy enough, all the materials are in the lectures which he posts online. Midterm and final are both jokes, hardest part is the lab exam, make sure you go to the lab review. He tells you exactly what you need to know to pass. Textbook is useless besides a few definitions needed for the exam.

Great professor. Lectures were heavy but also very interesting. She's a fair grader and I would definitely take another class with her. Participation matters because she would have pop up in-class assignments but as long as you do the readings before class then you're fine.

Seeing as Prof. Sorochan has such incredibly negative reviews, I felt the need to write my own because my experience with her has been so positive. I've taken COMS230 with her and now I'm in 210, and I've found her to be a wonderful lecturer who is highly intellectual. She's always willing to answer questions and ensure that students can succeed.

I don't understand why prof Sorochan gets such a low grade. Her lecture may not be the most interesting one, but the content is rich and organized. If you read the readings, it is very easy to get a high grade. Prof Sorochan is also very caring. She tries to remember students names even this class has a size of 200.

Although the content in COMS230 was quite interesting, Professor Sorochan is just dull. She talks very quickly without slides, sometimes uses the blackboard. One hour lectures feel much longer. Very heavy readings, 3 long ones a week. 5 papers based on the readings throughout the semester plus a term paper. Midterm and final are open book.

Lots of heavy readings, but you really don't need to do them. Class is graded fairly and the notes she posts online are enough to get you a good grade on the exams. Also, attendance is definitely optional. Is she a fun and engaging lecturer? No. Lectures are usually pretty boring. But the material is interesting, and the class is isn't tough.

The teacher is extremly bland and does not provide slides. COMS 230 is a fairly straightforward class, but this professor makes the course disinteresting and provides no slides. The course is basically set up with 3 (heavy) readings a week. 5 "Critical responses" each worth about 5%. A term paper worth 25%. Midterm worth 20%. And final work 30%.
She was nice and approachable, but not an effective lecturer at all. I really liked this class because of the material, but her lectures made me fall asleep. Fairly easy grader

A lot of readings, 3 long ones every week. Besides the readings, there is only one presentation, one paper, midterm and final exam (both open book). Talks way too fast, not clear as to what she really expects in her grading, expect to take lots of notes. Although lectures are only 50 minutes, they seemed much longer: too much content and monotone.

Probably the most boring class I've ever taken. Lectures are dull and too theoretical. Never draws on current events. Grading methods are poor. The class is about democracy yet the essay topics give you very limited freedom. How ironic.

Sorochan drags a 50 minute class in what seems 2 hours. The material is interesting, but she does not engage you with the material. Lectures are pretty boring and class is a bit too academic for my taste, which makes it not clear.
Goes slowly in class but covers everything well, kind of a tough grader with some things. Does make some good jokes.

Boring lectures, but they're comprehensive & summaries of textbook readings; Breakdown:Conference participation (20%), News assignment (15%) was pretty straightforward despite other comments (mark was TA-dependent), midterm (20%) was pretty hard- can write as much as you want for IDs but will still give u a 3/5, exam (40%)- easy bc. broad questions

I rate all my profs regardless of experience. Anthony is a pretty good prof. I really liked how his office hours are basically all the time and you can see him whenever. However, his grading criteria is quite unclear and the guidelines for assignments can be vague. Other than that he is pretty clear and I did like his style of teaching.

Prof is a nice guy. However, lecture is heavy and boring so most atudents just read the textbook or do the online recording. The midterm and final are confusing with no clear explanation. The assignment is not hard but need a lot of improvement for the instructions. Unless you like European politic, this course is hard for level 200.

Uninterested in his own lecture material and provides little to no guidelines for both the midterm/news assignment. His lectures are just summaries of the textbook and adds no extra depth to the class. Moreover, there are huge disparities in how conferences are managed by TAs. Would not recommend or take again.

Anthony needs a improvement. His tests are the stuff of nightmares, and both I and my TA were clueless as to what he wanted with the news assignment. However his lectures are well structured, and the way he presents the material is interesting. Plus I enjoy witnessing a young prof terrified of his students and their judgment.

Although Professor Imbrogno is a good Instructor, he is inexperienced. His lectures were clear and often interesting. Where he performed rather poorly, was in the manner in which he wrote the midterm and his unclear assignments. I think he wanted to give us easy yet challenging papers/tests but completely missed the mark. He seemed nice though.

Would definitely avoid this prof. One of the most rude and condescending I have ever had at Mcgill. Difficult to understand what he wants from you and inaccessible for clarification. Lectures were ok, however, tests and assignments were unclear. The prof was a really harsh and unfair grader.

Avoid. This prof is the least friendly I've had at McGill, rude in e-mails and sassy in his re-grades (not good sassy). Lectures were okay, but for exams and the paper it's really unclear what he wants. If you take the open instructions as such, you will loose a lot of points.

Pretty much every lecture was Prof Imbrogno elaborating on and explaining breif bullet points in his slides. The reading is a bit heavy, but if you do it all you'll do well. The midterms were nice and manageable. Didn't enjoy the class much at first but as time went on he became more relaxed and even funny. Nothing to worry about, would recommend.
